title: Using command line arguments with argv
Whenever a Python script is invoked from the command line, the user may supply additional
command line arguments
b
which will be passed on to the script. These arguments will be available to the programmer from the system variable
sys.argv
c
(“argv” is a traditional name used in most programming languages, and it means “
arg
b
ument
v
b
ector”).

inline_content.Text: Whenever a Python script is invoked from the command line, the user may supply additional
which will be passed on to the script. These arguments will be available to the programmer from the system variable
(“argv” is a traditional name used in most programming languages, and it means “

title: By convention, the first element in the
sys.argv
c
list is the name of the Python script itself, while the rest of the elements are the tokens passed by the user when invoking the script.

inline_content.Text: By convention, the first element in the
list is the name of the Python script itself, while the rest of the elements are the tokens passed by the user when invoking the script.

title:
# cli.py
import sys
print(sys.argv)

$ python cli.py
=> ['cli.py']

$ python cli.py fizz
=> ['cli.py', 'fizz']

$ python cli.py fizz buzz
=> ['cli.py', 'fizz', 'buzz']

content_resolved.code:
# cli.py
import sys
print(sys.argv)

$ python cli.py
=> ['cli.py']

$ python cli.py fizz
=> ['cli.py', 'fizz']

$ python cli.py fizz buzz
=> ['cli.py', 'fizz', 'buzz']

title: Here’s another example of how to use
argv
c

. We first strip off the initial element of sys.argv because it contains the script’s name. Then we combine the rest of the arguments into a single sentence, and finally print that sentence prepending the name of the currently logged-in user (so that it emulates a chat program).

inline_content.Text: Here’s another example of how to use

. We first strip off the initial element of sys.argv because it contains the script’s name. Then we combine the rest of the arguments into a single sentence, and finally print that sentence prepending the name of the currently logged-in user (so that it emulates a chat program).

title:
import getpass
import sys

words = sys.argv[1:]
sentence = " ".join(words)
print("[%s] %s" % (getpass.getuser(), sentence))

content_resolved.code:
import getpass
import sys

words = sys.argv[1:]
sentence = " ".join(words)
print("[%s] %s" % (getpass.getuser(), sentence))

title: The algorithm commonly used when “manually” parsing a number of non-positional arguments is to iterate over the
sys.argv
c
list. One way is to go over the list and pop each element of it:

inline_content.Text: The algorithm commonly used when “manually” parsing a number of non-positional arguments is to iterate over the
list. One way is to go over the list and pop each element of it:

title:
# reverse and copy sys.argv
argv = reversed(sys.argv)
# extract the first element
arg = argv.pop()
# stop iterating when there's no more args to pop()
while len(argv) > 0:
    if arg in ('-f', '--foo'):
        print('seen foo!')
    elif arg in ('-b', '--bar'):
        print('seen bar!')
    elif arg in ('-a', '--with-arg'):
        arg = arg.pop()
        print('seen value: {}'.format(arg))
    # get the next value
    arg = argv.pop()

content_resolved.code:
# reverse and copy sys.argv
argv = reversed(sys.argv)
# extract the first element
arg = argv.pop()
# stop iterating when there's no more args to pop()
while len(argv) > 0:
    if arg in ('-f', '--foo'):
        print('seen foo!')
    elif arg in ('-b', '--bar'):
        print('seen bar!')
    elif arg in ('-a', '--with-arg'):
        arg = arg.pop()
        print('seen value: {}'.format(arg))
    # get the next value
    arg = argv.pop()
